GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRÆUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suaskin every Wedesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m a steamer leaves Suez for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate streamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: OUR CONSULS.
div.p: Mr. Ernest William makes some suggestons in "The Standard" for improving our consular system, from the point of view of the commercial world. He would have Consuls placed under the control of the Board of Trade as well as of the Foreign Office, and he would compel them to pass examinations before appointment Consols, he argues, should be mapped out into two divisions—those in which owing to the lack of commerce or the preponderating character of other matters demanding the Consol's attention (such, for example, as certain of the posts in the Near Bast), the Board of Trade would not need to interfere, and the candidate would not need to hold a commercial diploma ; and those in which commerce is of importance. To the former class the Foreign Office coaid appoint, with or without power of veto in the Board of Trade ; to the other the Board of Trade could appoint, with simply power of veto in the Foreign Office.

But the mention of mapping out the world's British consulates calls to mind another reform which is needed. The consular posts themselves need to be rearranged and expended. Is it not, for example, ridiculous to have a Consul at Florence, where neither trade nor Oriental politics nor shipping demands such an officer, and at Milan, one of the chief centres of Italian industry, only a Vice-Consul, who need not be an Englishman, and who, we believe, only gets something like £60 a year, out of which he buys his own stationery. Of course, he can give but a small portion of his time to the important interests of British trade, which the Consul in that city might further. Why, again, should the Riviera possess numerous Consuls, while some important manufacturing towns in the interior of France possess none ? Most flagrant discrepancy of a 1, why should Austria-Hungary, a great and important commercial country, have but seven British Consuls, while little Greece has four teen ? Even in Germany the same thing is seen. The Empire contains but twenty-eight British consular officers ; and Spain has forty eight. All this must be changed. Of course, the Foreign Office mast be allowed to retain its consular representatives in places where here are real diplomatic reasons for a British representative, even though there be no trade, but there are many posts in which there is neither trade nor diplomacy to serve. By striking these off the list the number of commercial Consuls can he increased without increasing the total service.

Even, however, a total increase in the consular service must not be boggled at if good cause can be shown for representation in more places that the present number of Consuls would serve ; and there is one important direction io which a considerable increase in he total number of commercial consular officers is necessary. We refer to the Colonie?. With our Colonies we already do a third of our total foreign trade, and we expect to do with them a large proportion in the future; yet throughout the Daughter States of the Empire there is not a single Government official analogous to a Consul. It seems absurd ; yet, of course, one hw only to think what a Consul is—the representative of Great Britain in a foreign countryto see how it has come about that we have no Consuls in the Colonies. Consols so called, and fulfilling some of the functions of Consuls, we most continue to do without; but that is no reason why we should not have commercial Consuls, and thus is every reason why we should have plentiful supply of them. One obvious reason is that foreign Powers have their Consols in our Colonies busy furthering the trade of their respective nationalities, and as for practical purposes of business Australia and Canada are to us as much foreign markets as Japan or the United States, our trade suffers so long as the mannfactnrers of the Mother-country are not represented by Government officials in the Daughter States.

It is also suggested—and we are quoting now from proposal's made by consular officers themselves, who have given study to the question— that an inspector of Consuls should be appointed to visit the Consuls periodically and remove inefficient officers from their posts. This proposal is, we believe, to be embodied in the American reform.

We must find room in conclusion for one more reform. Consular officers should in all cases be in every sense Englishmen. Without casting any reflection upon the gentlemen serving as British Consols who are natives of the country to which they are appointed, it is obvious that their national ties most create some bias in favour of their own country—sufficient to mitigate their devotion to British trade; and it is noteworthy that one of the objects sought in the present reconstruction of the American consular service is the supersession of foreigners by Americans, to be obtained through such increase in remuneration as will permit Americans to fill the post It would pay us to follow America's example.
Deutsche Orient Bank.
A Cairo branch of the Deutsche Orient Bank will be opened at the Rond Point Suares in about a fortnight.
The Brindisi Mail.
The mail for Europe, viâ Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O, Alexandria, at 10.15 p.m. on Sunday.
Drowning Accident.
A native youth was drowned while swimming yesterday in the Mahmoudieh Canal. His body has not yet been recovered.
Coal Imports.
The imports of coal from January 1 to 10th inst. amounted to 460,251 tons, as compared to 293,292 during the same period last year.
A Canard.

There is no foundation whatever in the report published by a Cairo contemporary that the Comptoir d'Escompte de Paris had offered to purchase half of the land belonging to Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi, Ltd, in the Ismailia quarter of Cairo, at the rate of L.E. 30 a metre.
Mena House.

Mr. Emil Weckel and family are leaving Egypt to-day by the S.S. Semiramis for Venice and Leerne. Mena House Hotel passes over to-day to the George Nangovich Egyptian Hotel Company. The management of the hotel has been intrusted to Mr. Adolph Klingler, of the Continental Hotel, who has already taken up his post.
Opening of Markets.

A provincial correspondent writes: - It is rumoured that the markets will open soon for the sale of horned cattle. This would be a great boon to the fellah, as he has finished ploughing cotton, but cannot at present sell his animals, as he does every year. The opening of the markets would be a means of helping the sanitary authorities to seize any plaguestricken animals.
Alexandria Antiquities.

As from the 15th inst., the price of admission to the Greco-Roman Museum and to view Pompey's Pillar will be P.T. 1 and to Kom el Shougafa P.T. 3. The number of visitors to the Museum during the first four months of the year amounted to 2,130, as against 1,439 in the same period last year. 1,576 persons visited Pompey's Pillar, as against 1,299 last year, and 2,932 went over the Kom el Shou gafa excavation, as against 2,342 last year. The total receipts from all sources from January 1 to the end of April amounted to L.E. 178,990, compared with L.B. 224,090 during the same period last year, showing an increase of L.E. 45.
An Echo of Khartoum.

The order for 300 of the 2nd Battalion Royal Sussex Regiment to proceed from Crete to Egypt recalls the interesting fact that a detachment of the 1st Battalion got nearer to Khartoum when Gordon was besieged in it than any other regiment. The detachment consisted of 20 non-commissioned officers and men, under the command of Captain Lionel F. Trafford. It proceeded in one of Sir Charles Wilson's steamers from Metemmeh to within a short distance of Khartoum, but unfortunately the town had then fallen,and the gallant Gordon with it. Owing to the fact that the Royal Sussex Regiment was clothed in khaki this detachment borrowed scarlet jackets from the Guards in order that it might appear at Khartoum in the traditional uniform of the British army.
The Weather.

The following remarks on the week's weather at Alexandria are taken from Messrs. R. J Moss and Company's weekly circular-Wea ther perfect with the exception of sollen, overcast and a "twelve-hour-sun-obscured" Sunday, the 6th; when, with a S. W. ad, rain fall from 10 a. m. to 5 p. m., "off and on straight and solid," measuring 0.12 in., producing a raw chilliness and reducing the temperature to 54.0 Fahr.-This exception proves the rule that nothing under the sun is new our records show May-rainfalls A. D. 1886- 1888/9-1894/8. Sea bathers, generally amused in being tickled with a realistic shower bath, and foolish Virgins regret their too sudden change of winter covering to summer diaphanous garments. Average temperature for the 65.5 F. or 18.6 C., Maximum 76.1 F. or 24.5 C., week on 9th inst; Minimum 59.0 F. or 15.0 C., on the 6th inst.

div.head: THE DUMA'S SITTINGS.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, May 11.
Deputy Petrumkevitch said that the Dama was bound to devote its first free words to secure the freedom of the victims of liberty filling the prisons, whose release Russia demanded.

The siting was adjourned until Saturday. Demonstrations have become general throughout the Empire. Collisions between the troops and demonstrators have taken place at Warsaw, Simbirsk, and Kazan: many casualties are reported. (Reuter)
ST. PETERSBURG, May 11. The Council of the Empire has commenced its sittings. A large number of provincial towns were illuminated. (Havas

div.head: THE ITALIAN STRIKE.
div.p: COLLISION WITH TROOPS.
ROME, May 11. Collisions between the troops and strikers are occurring here and at Bologns. At Milan the strike is drawing to a close, but it is spreading at Genoa and Naples.
Signor Sonnino in the Chamber of Deputies said that the Government would vigorously repress the strike disorders which were provoked by the scum of the cities. He praised the conduct of the troops.
A Socialist motion, declaring legislation urgent to prevent a massacre of the proletariat, was rejected by 199 votes to 28.
(Reuter)
ROME, May 11.
The strike troubles continue here. All the shops are shut. The Socialist deputies have resigned in a body owing to the refusal of the Government to discountenance the employment of troops.
(Reut )
ROME, May 11.:
The Chamber of Labour has decided to
stop the strike.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: ULTIMATUM ENDS TO-MORROW.
FLEET TAKES ACTION IMMEDIATELY.
(Gazette's Special Service. )
London, Saturday.

The people of Great Britain are unanimously backing the Government. Mukhtar Pacha is considered to have notoriously been the head centre of an anti-British intrigue. No extension of time is to be granted. A mighty naval force is collected in Greek waters as an admirable effective instrument for bringing the Sultan to his senses.
LONDON, May 11.
Admiral Lambton, with the Thetis, Perseus, and Minerva, is at Port Said awaiting orders. The ultimatum expires at midnight on Sunday. The fleet takes action immediately afterwards.
The "Gazette" announces that Brigadier- General Bullock has been granted the temporary rank of Major-General. (Reuter)
LONDON. May 11.

HOUSE OF COMMONS.-Sir E. Grey stated that Turkey's claims raised issues far beyond the question of Tabah, Great Britain cannot refer the safety of the Suez Canal to arbitration. The best method of defining the frontiers was a joint commission, as Great Britain had proposed.
It is understood that General Paget is leaving Aldershot for Egypt. (Reuter)

CONSTANTINOPLE, May 11. Yesterday, Tewfik Pacha visited Sir Nicholas O'Conor, who rejected certain preposals, insist ing on absolute compliance with the demands made by the British Government. He reminded the Pacha that the term of grace was drawing to a conclusion. (Reuter)
Negotiations are still continuing,,,but there is nothing definite to announce.
We may assure our readers that the author. ities are quite capable of satisfactorily dealing with any disturbance in the unlikely event of its arising.

The news of the arrival of the greater part of the Mediterranean fleet at the Piræus and the measures taken in concert by the British and Egyptian military authorities have had a very tranquillising effect. The tone of the Pan- Islamic journals is much more subdned, and we have had no more wishes for the triumphant entry of the Turks into Cairo committed to print. We imagine that, while a certain proportion of the Moslems of Egypt are traditionally hostile to the Christian,a genuinely pro-Turkish sentiment is rare. It is not the Sultan of Turkey with whom the Egyptian Nationalist of the Right or Left sympathises, but the Imam el Mu'min'in.
SIGNIFICANT MEASURE.
There will be a route march of the troops forming the Alexandria garrison of the Army of Occupation on Monday morning next. The roops will march through the principal streets of the city.
NATIVE ATTITUDE.

It is noticeable that, although it cannot be said that there are any signs of agitation in Cairo, at the same time there has undoubtedly been a certain recrudescence of unrest among the lower orders during the last two or three days.
THE MOSQUES.

The sermons in the Mosques yesterday were free from any inflammatory references. During the last few months, however, the average attendance at the Cairo Mosques has increased by about fully fifty per cent and this is considered to be highly symptomatic.
NATIVE PRESS OF OPINION.

"El Omma," a Cairo vernacular paper, published an alleged telegram from Alexandria on Thursday announcing that a division of the Turkish Army had disembarked at Alexandria and had gone towards the Ghazi's Palace, where it had encamped.
"El Omma" then makes the following reflections on this telegram :-

"The threats and pretentions of her enemies has forced the Porte to send some troops to Alexandria. The Egyptians are receiving the soldiers of His Majesty with a manifest delight, and are keen in their hopes that victory will crown the arms of the Padishah."

"El Turk," the organ of Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha, in an editorial on the crisis, declares that if the Sultan surrenders he will lose all his prestige throughout the entire world of Islam. In the case of such a surrender, says our contemporary, it will be quite permissible for the heads of Islam to refuse allegiance henceforth to the Caliph and to declare that the Sultan is unfit to retain his position.

"Al Moayad" and "Al-Ahram" remark that the proj ot of marching British troops through some of the native quarters in Cairo is unnecessary and tasteless, and may have a contrary effect to what is aimed at by inciting the natives.

div.head: PROTECTING THE CANAL.
div.p: CLEARING FOR ACTION.
"READY AYE READY."
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Friday.

H.M.S. Minerva is still in harbour awaiting orders. This morning the crew were busy constructing extra fighting tops above the ordinary ones, and clearing for action. Six gunboats are supposed to be within wireless distance, five along the coast. There are also three in harbour. The men-of-war are to enter the Canal at the end of the Ultimatum period and patrol the Canal with the assistance of troops.The ships in the Canal will have Maxims on board with a range of 1 miles. Ten gunboats are expected to be stationed in the Canal.

div.head: GUARDSHIP FOR SUEZ.
div.p: FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Suez, Saturday.
H.M.S. cruiser Perseus will arrive here tonight from Port Said and will presumably be stationed as a guardship for Suez.

div.head: FRENCH MISSIONS TO THE SUDAN.
div.p: Messrs. Bonnel de Mézières and Raymond Colrat, who have been exploring the Sudan on behalf of the French Ministry of the Colonies and the Paris Geographical Society, are now in Cairo, when M.Colrat had an hour's conference with Lord Cromer.

M. de Mézières journeyed through the Egyptian Soudan, crossed the region of the Blue and White Nile, and thoroughly investigated Kordofan. His report on those regions is of great interest in regard to their administration, economic value, and their political relations with the French Colonies, especially the Wady Oasis. There is in this report & study of the several Mohammedan questions that are so interesting just at the present critical hour.

M. Colrat, who is a Councillor of the French Board of Foreign Trade and is a Chevalier of the Legion of Honour, will be remembered by all interested in France's African Colonies for a lecture he once delivered at the Geographical Society on Tunisia.

div.head: REPORTED DEATH OF IBN RACHID.
div.p: An Arab notable of Ismailia has learnt from Basra that Abdul Aziz ibn Rachid of Haïl has been killed in battle by Abdul Aziz ibn Sa'ond the Wahabi ruler of Nejd in Central Arabia Another report has reached Egypt to the effect that Ibn Rachid was killed by conspirators suborned by Ibn Saoud. Ibn Rachid was by turns the ally, enemy, and vassal of the Ottoman Government. We are not informed of his precise position at the time of his death.

div.head: EGYPT'S MINERAL WEALTH.
div.p: Mr. Wells, Inspector General of Mines, concludes his report on the mining industry of Egypt with an optimistic forecast. He says-Finally, I may perhaps repeat an opinion which I have already expressed, viz., that the extent and distribation of the various mineral belts in Egypt are such as to warrant the expenditure of capital in their development; that the economic conditions existing are good, but that it will take at least ten years of active prospecting and development to prove the commercial possibilities of the many mineral belt. Outside of the heavy minerals and gold, there are, in my opinion, very considerable possibilities in the deposits of phosphates and nitrates, chiefly for internal consumption, and also in the various building stones available in the Eastern Desert. The latter occur in great variety, and are many of them of exceptional beauty. I hope that in the near future it may be possible to arrange for an exhaustive inquiry into the above."

div.head: AGRICULTURAL BANK OF CYPRUS.
div.p: The Agricultural Bank of Cyprus has been started, and an office has been opened at Famagusta, where the old Venetian harbour has been reopened by the British Government and a railway made thence to Nicosia. The line is nearly completed to Morphu at the West end of the Island. The bank will open other branches shortly. It will be entirely under the management of the Egyptian Land Allotment Company.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
Par suite de l'amélioration des nouvelles concernant le conflit d'Akaba, toute la cote a repris. Ce sont évidemment les valeurs injustement dépréciées qui ont le plus bénéficié de ce revirement.
De ce nombre sont la Delta Light qui regagne 3/8 à 12 1/4, l'Agricole 3/16 à 9 15 16 la National Bank 3/8 à 26 9/16, la Daïra 3/16
Nile

à 17 3/8, etc. L'Union Foncière est demandée à 6 3/8. En hausse également l'Anglo-American à 5 3/4, la Barque d'Athènes à 149, la Nile Land à 15 3/4, l'Investment à 1 5/16, la Land Bank à 9 3/16, le Trust à 1 9/16 et l'Urbaine à 6 1/8.
La corbeille a présenté ce matin une surexcitation extraordinaire au moment de la hausse

de la Delta Land à 4 1/8, en gain de 3/16 sur le cours de clôture d'hier. Comme un arrangement est imminent entre l'Angleterre et la Tarquie à propos du diffé rend qui les divise, cette reprise ne fera probablement que s'accentuer.
THE NEW A.A.G.
COL. CUTHBERT'S CAREER.
The papers state that Colonel Cuthbert has been appointed Assistant Adjutant-General in Egypt. (Reuter)

The newly appointed A.A.G. in Egypt will be a gain to the Army of Occupation, for during his command of the 1st Battalion Scots Guards he was recognised as a first-rate commanding officer. When Mr. Haldane, Secretary of State for War, paid an official visit to Aldershot the other day, he was taken to see this battalion by the General commanding there as an example of a battalion of Guards in the highest state of efficiency, and he expressed himself in the warmest terms of praise concerning it.

Colonel Gerald James Cuthbert, who was only relieved of the command of his battalion on the 22nd inst., had a family connection with that regiment. Colonel Cuthbert was born in 1861, the fifth son of William Cuthbert of Beaufront Castle, Northumberland, and his nephew, who is the present representative of the family, served in the Scots Guards as a lieutenant. His period of service extends to nearly a quarter of a century, and his war record includes the Sudan Expedition of 1885, when with the 2nd Bat- talion of his regiment he was present at Hasheen and Temai, and the South African campaign. He shared in the advance on Kimberley, including the engagements at Modder River and Magersfontein, and he also took part in many other actions. For his services. he received the brevet of Lieutenant-Colo nel, the medal with six clasps, and the King's medal with two clasps.
His appointment will be received with satisfaction, for it was generally recognised that the penalty inflicted on him in the recent "ragging" case was disproportionate.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive came to Ras-el-Tin Palace this morning, and presided over a Council of Ministers.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers met this morning at Ras el-Tin Palace, under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive, when the following decisions were arrived at :-
To improve the position of employés whose salaries are under L.E. 10 a month.
To increase the pay of the daily employés of the Native Courts.
To extend the Mahmoudieh Canal in Assiout Modirieh.
To construct a deviation for the canal of Mit el Liss and Cheikh Ramadan in the Mehalla Kobra Markaz.
To retain as a State monopoly the working of wireless telegraphy in Egypt.
To sanction an electrical and mechanical
company.
To sanction an Egyptian publishing company. To sanction a motor traction company. To sanction the Cairo Public Motor-car Company.

div.head: LAUNCH OF NEW KHEDIVIAL LINER.
div.p: The new vessel which has been built for the Khedivial Mail Line was successfully launched on the 9th inst. at the yard of Messrs. Swan and Hunter by Wallsend-on-Tyne, the vessel receiving the name of Osmanieh on leaving the ways.

The Osmanieh is a fine vessel of about 5,000 tons register, fitted with twin-screw quadruple engines of great power, estimated to give a sea speed of 18 knots an hour. Her accommodation, which is all above the main deck, is for 150 first-class and 80 second-class passengers. It will be of the most up-to-date and luxurious character with many suites de luxe, and a large number of spacious two-berth cabins on the upper decks.

The vessel is expected to arrive at Alexandria in August, when it is the intention of the company to put her into their Greece- Turkey line under a special express itinerary by which the passage to Athens will be reduced to 30 hours, and to Constantinople to 48 hours, thus bringing Alexandrie, by the shortest and calmest sea route, within five days of Paris and London by the Orient Express train de luxe service from Constantinople. A handsome model of the new vessel will be on show during the summer at the Milan International Exhibition.

div.head: DISTRIBUTION OF LAND.
div.p: During the last few years Lord Cromer states that the distribution of land as between Earo peans and natives does not appear to have undergone any material change. In 1900, 6,347 Europeans held 586,149 acres of land. In 1904, 6,165 Europeans held 630,925 acres. Thus it would appear that the number of European proprietors has diminished, whilst the acreage which they hold "has somewhat increased. In 1900, 908,067 native proprietors held 4,527,903 acres of land. In 1904, 1,083,877 native proprietors held 4.635,659 acres. It would appear, therefore, that both the number of native proprietors and the aggregate amount of land held by them have increased.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sir William Garstin, Adviser to the Public Works Department, is going to Europe on leave on the 30th June.
The Marquis Medici de Maregnani, the newly-appointed Italian Vice-Consul at Cairo in succession to M. Chelesotti, is arriving at Cairo to-morrow to take up his duties.
M. Chelesotti, appointed acting Italian Consul at Santa Flora in Brazil, is leaving Egypt on Thursday next for South America.
Captain Halse, R.E., has arrived at Alexandria and taken over the command of the Royal Engineers here, recently vacated by Captain Gordon.
Captain C. Barroughs, Assistant Provost Marshal, Cairo, is leaving for England, accom panied by his wife and family, by she 8.8. Herefordshire,sailing from Port Said to-morrow.
We are glad to hear Mr. J. Home, Sub- Governor of the National Bank of Egypt, who is suffering from typhoid fever, is making good progress towards recovery.

Miss Ethel M. Tarne the young and promising water-colour artiste from South Kensington, who has been paying a flying visit to Egypt, has been most successful with the two lotteries of her drawings in Cairo and Alexandria. The winner of the first prize in Alexandria was M. Zervadachi and in Cairo. M. Cariel, who obtained an exquisite view ot Bombay Harbour. Miss Tarner, who leaves for England on Monday taking with her a few sketches of Cairo scenery, hopes to return next
season.

Mr. Longworth has left Nairobi and the latest issue of the "Globe Trotter" conta ins the following announcement from the acting editor:-"In Mr. Longworth's absence I have been left to try and bring the paper out in my best style, but I am afraid the task is beyond my power to compete with a man whose experience and brain capacity can only be put on a level with some great London editor of years of experience and a ready flow of words to express current events in the most explicit manner. I will act upon my chief's last word:- 'Do your beat.'"

div.head: Circulaire H. De Tries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, mercredi 9 Mai.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres vient d'être élevé à 4 pour cent Hier, au stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est remonté de 1/4, après avoir perdu 3/8 la veille. L'Unifiée, la National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daïra sont encore restées invariées à leurs cours précédents. La Delta Light a regagné 1/8 5 12 3/8
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a clôturé a 779. soit en nouvelle hausse de 4 francs. La Banque d'Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 150.

Notre marché des valeurs a été, ce matin encore, inactif et lourd; avec une petite accentuation de la tendance à la dépression. A peu d'exceptions près, les titres ont payé, plus ou moins, leur tribut à la réaction.

Les optimistes prédisent avec assurance la fin de cette série de mauvaises séances. Ils se basent, paraît-il, d'un côté sur la conviction que le resserrement monétaire a Londres aurait atteint son apogée ; de l'autre côté sur l'espoir que le différend turco-anglais serait certainement appelé à recevoir une solution pacifique a l'approche de l'expiration de l'ultimatum.

La National Bank est restée délaissée 5 26 9/32. L'Agricole a faibli à 9 7/8. Le Comptoir Financier a été inscrit 5 6 1/4, ex-right ; l'action nouvelle a été cotée £6. La Cassa di Sconto a rétrogradé a 215 et la nouvelle émission 5 212 ; la Banque d'Athènes a 148 et la Banque d'Orient à 136. La Banque d'Abyssinie s'est réveillée 5 6 1/2.

L'action Crédit Foncier est restée immobile 5 780. La Nile Land a avancé 5 16 9/16 pour fléchir en clôture 5 16 3/8 vendeurs. Il se confirme que l'achat du restant da domaine de Kasr-el-Doubara rencontre des obstacles sérieux.

L'Immobilière a faibli a 366; la part de fondateur a 615. L'Agricole du Nil est également revenue a 273; la part de fondateur a 8 3/8. L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux est restée a 4 1/4 ; la part de fondateur a 78.
La Brasserie des Pyramides a fléchi a 133 et la part de dividende 5 63.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont été traités a 17 7/16 et les Baehler a 5 L'Anglo-American s'est raffermi a 5 1/2.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta ont ete ramenés a 4 3/16 ; les Egyptian Constructions: 5 15/16; les Glymenopoulo a 1 1/2 et les Abdy a 1 5/16-8/8.

La Société des Exceleior Hotels vient de conclure l'achat des terrains contigus a ceux qu'elle possédait déjà au rond-point Soliman-Pacha. Bile dispose donc actuellement d'environ 5,500 mètres carrés de terrain, dont une partie pourra être revendue dans des conditions très avantageuses.

M. Dattari, le cédant du premier lot acheté par le syndicat qui a constitué la Société, a réclamé le paiement immédiat du solde qui lui était dû sur ce terrain. Bien qu'au dire du contentieux de la Société, cette réclamation fût mal fondée, on a pris les mesures nécessaires pour le règlement de cette somme. Les tribunaux auront a se prononcer sur les dommages que la Société estime lui avoir été causés de ce chef.
Un second versement de L.E. 1 par action sera probablement appelé vers le 15 Juin proohain.
On rapporte que l'émission de la Commercial, Industrial and Land Co. of Egypt a été largement ouverte.
On ajoute que la Société serait en négocia­tions pour la conclusion de deux ou trois nouvelles affaires très promettantes.
L'assemblée générale ordinaire des actionnaires de la Nungovich Hotels Co. est convoquée pour le jeudi 31 Mai courant, 5 4 h. p.m., au siège social au Caire.
A l'ordre du jour : rapport du conseil; présentation des comptes de l'exercice 1905, fixation da dividende, élection d'administrateurs, etc.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

— Les détenteurs d'actions et parts de fondateur de la Land Bank of Egypt sont informés que les dividendes de £0.7.6 par action an­cienne, de P.E. 6,75 par action nouvelle et de £ 1.2 eh. par part de fondateur sont payables 5 partir du 15 du courant, 5 Alexandrie, contre présentation du coupon No 1.
— Un avis de la Nungovieh Hotels Co. porte que le second versement de £ 4 sur les actions nouvelles peut être effectué le 30 Mai courant, au lieu de la date précédemment
prescrite du 15 Mai.

div.head: Royal Insurance Company.
div.p: NOTICE,

Messrs. Haselden and Co., Egyptian Agents for the Royal Insurance Company of Liverpool, hereby beg to inform their clients that having regard to the widespread uneasiness which the San Francisco disaster has created in the minds of the public generally, the Directors of the Royal Insurance Company have made the following official announcement:—
" The Royal Insurance Company has
" learnt by cablegram from its Manager at
" San Francisco that the area of the recent
" disaster involves a possible liability of
" £1,350,000 (6,750,000dols.). Having regard
" however to the large balance at the credit
" of Profit and Loss at the end of 1904, and
" the profitable results of last year's opera-
" tions, the payments which will have to be
" made in connection wit,h this liability will
" not necessitate any reduction in the Fire
" and Reserve Funds of the Compary."

It is anticipated that when the Manager of the Company at San Francisco has been able to look closely into the position it will transpire that the Company's losses will be appreciably less than the figure mentioned. 27888-4-1
